A COLLECTOR WHOSE PASSION IS SAVING OLD HOUSES 

   (For release Sunday, August 27)   By RITA REIF  
       
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   STOCKHOLM, Sweden _ Lars Sjoberg dates his obsession with old
Swedish houses to 1951, when, at age 10, his mother gave him a book
from his grandfather's library on manors and villas from centuries
past.

   ``For two years after that, I was always drawing houses and
making models of them,'' he said. ``And some looked like the
earliest and smallest of the six I own today, a red timber house
called Sorby in a tiny village of that name.''

   Built like an American log cabin in the 17th century, Sorby,
about 130 miles southwest of here, was updated a century later to
look like a manor house: the windows were enlarged and the grass
roof replaced by a mansard roof, with small glass panes in the
short wall between the two levels, to admit light into the attic.
``In some ways it's my favorite house,'' Sjoberg said.

   Some people collect Hula-Hoops, cookie jars, Japanese screens or
even racing cars; Sjoberg collects houses. What began as a
childhood fancy became a reality when he needed places to live, and
it evolved into a compulsion when he saw old houses about to be
torn down.

   His passion to save houses is perhaps rooted in his father's
belief that he could make and repair most anything. His father
taught wood and metal crafting at the boarding school near
Stockholm that Lars Sjoberg and his two sisters attended and where
the family lived. ``He taught me that everything is possible for a
carpenter,'' Sjoberg said. ``I'm trying but not always
succeeding.''

   When Sjoberg was a teen-ager, the family built a simple modern
house near the school. ``Even then, I longed for something
old-fashioned,'' he said.

   His interest deepened when he studied art history and
architecture at Stockholm University. After he graduated in 1965
and became an assistant curator of art at the National Museum, he
grew even more determined to make old houses part of his life. So
he and his bride, Ursula, also a budding art historian, began
living in a timber house on his family's property while they hunted
for an old manor house they could call home.

   The first house Sjoberg bought, 35 years ago, was Regnaholm, a
splendid 18th-century white and yellow manor house that he now says
was too large, too expensive and too distant from Stockholm _ 120
miles southwest in Ostergotlund. But the house was facing
demolition, so he and his family pooled their resources and bought
it as a vacation house. At the time, Swedish preservationists were
not yet protesting the razing of 18th-century buildings because, as
Sjoberg said, many still existed and preserving old houses seemed
elitist to those campaigning for low-cost housing.

   The couple searched for nine years before they found their
perfect house, Odenslunda, a five-room manor house in Uppland, only
18 miles from Stockholm. Built in 1775 for the military, it was,
Sjoberg said, ``the largest type made for a colonel.'' The house
was made of timbers, stone and bricks and covered with wooden
vertical siding and had an attic.

   Today, Sjoberg, 59, a senior curator at the museum, uses his
houses, built between 1680 and 1830, for his workshops on
architectural restoration, a program he conducts for Stockholm
University. In addition to manors, he owns an 18th-century
Italianate villa, an 1830s country inn and an 1810 building that
housed the families of factory workers.

   In the early '90s, Sjoberg was a consultant to Ikea and designed
a line of traditional Swedish furniture, lighting and accessories
for the chain. He has written several books on Swedish furniture;
his best-known work, ``The Swedish Room,'' a collaboration with
Sjoberg, who is now a curator of the Royal Collections, includes
four of their houses.

   All of Sjoberg's houses reflect the French-influenced Gustavian
style of the 18th century. The look was shaped in part by the
architect Carl Harleman, who had visited Versailles before
designing the interiors of the Royal Palace in Stockholm. He
brought back to Sweden the mansard roof, tall narrow multipaned
windows, crystal chandeliers, pastel and white color schemes,
neo-Classical furnishings, floral patterned fabrics and wallpapers
and gilded rococo embellishments.

   This style flourished in Swedish palaces and homes, and lives on
in turn-of-the-century paintings by Carl Larsson and in the films
of Ingmar Bergman. Lars Sjoberg is also reviving the style in the
rooms of palaces he has decorated and the houses he has collected,
using techniques he learned from master craftsmen decades ago or
discovered on his own or through teaching.

   ``My students, all 20 of them, practice restoration,'' he said.
``They are learning how to mix plaster and apply it thinly to the
walls the way they did in the 18th century.'' They also stucco
ceilings and dismantle and reassemble porcelain stoves to repair
them. The most difficult task, he says, is scraping layers of paint
from walls, to get down to the original surfaces. ``You have to
know what you should look for _ not the raw wood, but the first
layer of paint,'' he said. ``And you have to know what to do with
what you find: don't repaint the wall. Instead, when you strip off
the layers, leave the original painted surface, worn though it may
seem.''

   The secret to restoration, he said, often has more to do with
what you remove than what you add. The windows at Regnaholm, he
says, still have the original glass panes. Nearly clear but lightly
tinted green, they produce a wondrous light when left uncovered on
sunny days.

   ``And at Sorby, all the rooms still have the painted canvas wall
decoration, from 250 years ago, faded but intact,'' he said. ``The
Gustavian lightness is back again.''
